journal.name: Set your personal teaching goal for differentiated instruction
journal.intro:
Set a goal for incorporating strategies for differentiated instruction (DI) into your teaching practice. If you currently address and incorporate DI strategies into your teaching, write a goal that increases your focus on DI in your lesson planning and design. The purpose of setting a goal is to help you have an end in mind, i.e., a way to refine your practice of teaching.

Connecting our success as teachers to our students' success as learners is a hot topic these days in educational policy in K-12. What's a fair assessment of student learning? Here is an example from one of your peers in the cohort who combines student feedback on her instruction and their own learning with level gains based on standardized tests:

I would like to apply the writing improvement techniques and strategies I am learning in this course to the content of my classes. Assess after course completion which were effective, based upon my reflection and student feedback. I would like feedback from 50% of my students that they feel their writing has improved. I would also like them to witness level gains in their classes and progress in their meeting their own individual goals.

Now that you've learned more about the importance of goal setting, monitoring, and attribution of effort to success, set a goal for yourself in the DI course.

Write your goal so that it isÂ tied to your circumstances, and reflective of your commitment to be a more effective teacher of adult students.
